awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project it to reduce the impact of future earthquakes.  This smartphone-based crowdsource sensing application provides earthquake alerts and shaking hazard data. The vision is to provide earthquake early warning around the globe, and collect data on building performance.  Warnings can be used to slow and stop trains reducing the likelihood of derailment, to isolate hazardous chemicals and machinery to reduce damage, to move data to safe storage, and to signal individuals to move to a safe place.  Shaking data recoded in buildings can also be used to assess the performance of a building during an earthquake.  Recorded shaking in smaller non-damaging quakes can be used to predict building performance in larger events.  The data recorded by application enabled phones can potentially be used by structural engineers to assess buildings, and can be used by the insurance industry to set premiums.

This I-Corps project develops a global smartphone-based seismic network.  The technology uses machine learning techniques to distinguish between earthquakes and other sources of shaking as recorded on personal/private smartphones, and is embedded in the application that has been downloaded by over 250,000 users around the world.  When a phone detects an earthquake, it notifies a central server.  The server confirms the earthquake based on multiple phone detection, and estimates the size and location.  An alert could then be issued to users.  At the same time, the phone records the ground shaking during the earthquake.  This timeseries data can be used for a range of purposes including fundamental research on earthquake processes, and characterization of buildings.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA, THE

por.por_cntn:
The MyShake app is a smartphone app that can detect earthquake shaking, record the ground motion in earthquakes, upload this data for analysis, and receive real-time earthquake information including alerts of forthcoming ground motion.  You can download the free app from the iTunes or Google Play stores (https://myshake.berkeley.edu/).

Through the I-Corps program, members of the MyShake team learned how to use customer discovery to identify who could make use of the app and the earthquake information it provides.  We learned that individuals, specifically the public in earthquake prone regions were the users who saw most value in the product.  

We then started to explore who would be willing to pay to provide these alerts to the public and identified two primary customers:

1. The State of California. The state now funds the ongoing operation and development of MyShake as part of the California Earthquake Early Warning System (see https://earthquake.ca.gov/). 1.8 million users have downloaded the app, mostly in California, and now receive alerts and earthquake information through the app.

2. Google.  We transfered the MyShake technology to the Google Android eco system. This included licencing of the IP and also a collaboration between the MyShake team and members of the Android Earthquake Team. The Android Earthquake Alerts system is currently delivering earthquake alerts in dozens of countries and announced its plans to roll-out in high earthquake hazard countries around the globe later this year.  

As a result of this award, the technology to detect earthquakes with smartphones, and to deliver earthquake alerts to smartphones has matured to the point that it is being used globally to reduce injury and fatalities in earthquakes.


Last Modified: 07/01/2022
Modified by: Richard Allen
